turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Did you read in the paper today, about the man who was walking his dog?  he was attacked, and his wallet and his watch were taken.  And then, while he was still lying unconscious, his attacker stabbed him with a knife in both eyes.  It happened four blocks from here.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: I heard.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I have no understanding of this place anymore.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: It's always been like this.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: Well, there he sits.  It's not supposed to make sense.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: He's not finished.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: How you feeling?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I can breathe withour pain now, so I guess I feel great.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Thank you.  Tell them, thank you.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: We figure you need all the tools you can get to fix up that piece of shit you call a house.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Yeah, that's true.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: They're hoping you stop and say goodbye before you go, but I told them not to expect it.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: It would be too hard.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: He's being arraigned tomorrow.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I read about it in the paper.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: I guess... decide for yourself.  I don't know what it says.  I'm going to go.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I'll see you.

turns.speaker: CRAZED MAN
turns.text: And... and... and he said... he asked me if I was married.  And, I could see he had a gun in his hand.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Where was the girl?

turns.speaker: CRAZED MAN
turns.text: What?  What?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Where was the prostitute?  Where was she?

turns.speaker: CRAZED MAN
turns.text: She was... she was on the bed.  She was just sitting on the bed.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Who tied her down?  You or him?

turns.speaker: CRAZED MAN
turns.text: He had a gun.  He had a gun... and he made it happen.  He made me do it!  He made me put that... that thing on.  Oh, Christ!  He made me wear it... and... and he told me to fuck her.  He had the gun in my mouth.

turns.speaker: DELIVERYMAN
turns.text: Jesus Christ, man, don't shoot me!

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Turn around.  Hands on your head!

turns.speaker: DELIVERYMAN
turns.text: What the hell's going on?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Who are you?  What are you doing out here?

turns.speaker: DELIVERYMAN
turns.text: I'm... I'm just delivering a package.

turns.speaker: DELIVERYMAN
turns.text: This guy paid me five hundred bucks to bring it out here.  He wanted it here at exactly seven o'clock.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Put it down.  Put it on the ground.

turns.speaker: DELIVERYMAN
turns.text: Okay...

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I don't believe it.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I mean, at this point, what would it hurt if you told us a little about yourself?

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: It doesn't matter who I am.  Who I am means absolutely nothing.  You need to turn left here... at the traffic light.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: What's so exciting?

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: It's not too far away now.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: What time is it?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: It's surprising how easily a member of the press can purchase information from the men in your precinct.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: David... please...

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: I visited your home this morning, after you left.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Give me the gun.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: Her pretty head.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: You didn't know.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: NO!

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Where we headed?

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: You'll see.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: We're not just going to pick up two more bodies, are we, Johnny?  That wouldn't be... shocking enough.  Wouldn't keep you on the front page of the newspapers.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: Wanting people to pay attention, you can't just tap them on the shoulder.  You have to hit them in the head with a sledgehammer. Then, you have their strict attention.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: What makes you so special that people should pay attention?

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: Not me.  I'm not special.  I'm not exceptional.  This is, though.  What I'm doing.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I hate to burst your bubble, but other than the fact that you're especially sadistic, there's nothing unusual about these precious murders of yours.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: You know that's not true.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: In two months, no one's going to even remember this happened.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: You can't see the whole... the whole complete act yet.  Not yet.  But, when this is done, it's going to be... so... so...

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Spit it out.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: It's going to be flawless.  People will barely be able to comprehend it.  It will seem almost surreal... but it will have a tangible reality, so they won't be able to deny it.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: I can't wait for you to see.  I can't wait...  It's really going to be something.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Well, I'll be standing beside you the whole time, so you be sure to let me know when this whole, complete reality thing is done.  Wouldn't want to miss it.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: Oh, don't worry. You won't...

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: I... I doubt I enjoyed it any more than... Detective Mills would enjoy some time alone with me in a room without windows.  Isn't that true?  How happy would it make you to hurt me, with impunity?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Now... I wouldn't do something like that, Johnny.  I like you.  I like you a lot.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: You wouldn't because you know there are consequences.  It's in those eyes of yours, though... nothing wrong with a man taking pleasure in his work.  I won't deny my own personal desire to turn each sin against the sinner.  I only took their sins to logical conclusions.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: You only killed a bunch of innocent people so you could get your rocks off.  That's all.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: Innocent?  Is that supposed to be funny? Look at the people I killed.  An obese man, a disgusting man who could barely stand up... who if you saw him on the street, you'd point so your friends could mock him along with you.  Who if you saw him while you were eating, you wouldn't be able to finish  your meal.  After him I picked the lawyer.  And, you both must have been secretly thanking me for that one.  This was a man who dedicated his life to making money by lying with every breath he could muster... to keeping rapists and murderers on the streets.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Murderers?

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: A woman...

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Murderers like you?

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: A woman... so ugly on the inside that she couldn't bare to go on living if she couldn't be beautiful on the outside.  A drug dealer... a drug dealing pederast, actually.  And, don't forget the disease spreading whore.  Only in a world this shitty could you even try to say these were innocent people and keep a straight face.  That's the point.  You see a deadly sin on almost every street corner, and in every home, literally.  And we tolerate it. Because it's common, it seems trivial, and we tolerate, all day long, morning, noon and night.  Not anymore.  I'm setting the example, and it's going to be puzzled over and studied and followed, from now on.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Delusions of grandeur.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: You should be thanking me.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: And, why is that?

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: You're going to be remembered, and it's all because of me.  And, the only reason I'm here right now is because I wanted to be.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: We would have gotten you eventually.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: Really?  Just biding your time, then? Toying with me.  Is that it?  Letting five people die until you finally felt like going out and hauling me in?

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: Tell me what it was that gave me away. What was the piece of evidence you were going to use against me right before I walked up to YOU and put my hands in the air.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I seem to remember knocking on your door.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: And, I remember breaking your nose.  You're only alive because I didn't kill you.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Sit back.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Just keep leading the way.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: It's close.

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: I wish I could have been a normal man like you.  I wish I could have a simple life.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: What the fuck is going on here?!

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: You've made a good life for yourself...

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Shut up!

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: Here he comes.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: What the fuck is going on?

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: I want you to know, I wish I could have lived like you do.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Somerset...

turns.speaker: JOHN DOE
turns.text: Because I envy your normal life.  Envy is my sin.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I'm a little thrown.  I just got in town like twenty minutes ago and they dumped me here.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Since we're just starting out, I thought we could go to a bar... sit and talk for awhile.  After that, we'll...

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Actually, if it's all the same, I'd like to get to the precinct house a.s.a.p.  Seeing how we don't have much time for this whole transition thing.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I need to start getting the feel of it all, right?  Meet the people.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I meant to ask you something, Mills, when we spoke on the phone.  I can't help wondering... why here?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I... I don't follow.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: All this effort you've made to get transferred, it's the first question that pops into my head.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I'm here for the same reasons as you, I guess.  Or, at least, the same reasons you used to have for being here before... before you decided to... quit.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: You just met me.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Maybe I'm not understanding the question.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: It's very simple.  You worked a nice, quiet town, but you fought to get here as if your life depended on it.  I've just never seen it done that way before, Detective.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Maybe I thought I could do more good here than there.  I don't know.  Look, it'd be great by me if we didn't start right off kicking each other in the balls.  But, you're calling the shots, Lieutenant, so... however you want it to go.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Let me tell you how I want this to go.  I want you to look, and I want you to listen.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I wasn't standing around guarding the local Taco Bell.  I've worked homicide for five and a half years.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Not here.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I realize that.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Well, over the next seven days, do me the favor of remembering it.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I wonder what exactly was the point of the conversation you were about to get into?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: And I wonder how many times Officer Davis there has found a dead man who wasn't really dead until Davis was in the car calling it in and eating a donut.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Drop it.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: For now.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Who said this was murder?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: No one yet.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Then, why are we wasting our time?  This guy's heart's got to be roughly the size of a canned ham.  If this isn't a coronary, I don't know what is.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: When we found him, he was lying there with a knife in his back, so what else could it be but homicide?  Except, I finally figured out... he held the knife behind him... put the tip of it in his own back and got real close to the wall... then he shoved his body backwards...

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Please be quiet for a while, would you?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: There's a bucket here.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: There's a bucket.  Under the table.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: It's a bucket of vomit.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Is there any blood in it?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I don't know.  Feel free to look for yourself, okay?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: You think it was poison?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Guessing at this point is useless.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: You've seen my files, right?  Seen the things I've done?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Anyway... I did my time on door-to-doors, and walking a beat.  I did all that shit for a long time.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: The badge in my pocket says "detective," same as yours.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I made a decision, because I have to consider the integrity of the scene.  I can't worry whether you think you're getting enough time on the playing field.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Yeah, well, all I want is...  Just, just don't be jerking me off.  That's all I ask.  Don't jerk me off.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Is that clear?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Okay... sure...  It's just that, with my old partner, you know...

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I just don't think we should have that sort of relationship.  We'd start quarreling over insignificant things.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Same color and texture.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Have you found any plastic scrapings near the stove or sink?  Near the food?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: This doesn't make any sense.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: You always have to find one singular thing to focus on.  There's always one thing, and it may be as small as a speck of dust, but you find it and focus... till it's an exhausted possibility.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: It could be nothing.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: But, why would there be so many pieces in his stomach if it were nothing?  It must have been intentional.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: He ate his fill, and was forced to continue eating... till his body rejected the food. the killer held a bucket under him, and then kept serving.  He took his time.  The coroner says this might have gone on for more than twelve hours.  The victim's throat was swollen from the effort, and there was probably a point where he passed out.  That's when killer kicked him in the stomach.  Popped him.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: This was one sadistic motherfucker.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: This is his stuff.  I've been out in the cold all day.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: This is a premeditated puzzle, and it's only the beginning.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I'm declining this case.  I want us reassigned.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Whoa, whoa... what?!

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: It's too soon for him.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Can we talk about this in private?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: It's a package deal.  You get the phone with the office.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Detective Mills here.  Honey... I asked you not to call me here. I'll call you back...  What?  Why?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: It's my wife.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I'm invited to have a late supper at your house.  And, I accept.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: How's that?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Tonight.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I'd like you to meet Somerset.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: All television does is teach children that it's really cool to be stupid and eat candy bars all day.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: What about sports?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: What about them?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: You go to movies at least?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I read.  Remember reading?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I just have to say, I can't respect any man who's never seen "Green Acres."

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: You've never seen "The Odd Couple?"  This is sick.  "The Honeymooners?!"

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I vaguely recall a large, angry man, and someone called Norton.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Our guy got into office, probably before the building closed and security tightened up.  Gould must have been working late.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I'm certain.  He was the biggest defense lawyer around.  Infamous, actually.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Well, his body was found Monday night, okay?  But, get this... the office was closed all day Monday.  Which means, as long as the gluttony killing was done before the weekend, our killer could've gotten in here on Friday.  He could've spent all day Saturday with Gould, and all day Sunday.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: The leather chair was soaked through with sweat.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: All day Saturday, and all day Sunday.  The murderer would want Gould to take his time.  To have to sit there and decide. Where do you make the first cut?  There's a gun in your face... but, what part of your body is expendable?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: He cut along the side of his stomach.  The love handle.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: He must have left another puzzle piece.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Look, I appreciate being able to talk this out, but, uh...

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: This is just to satisfy my curiosity.  I'm still leaving town Saturday.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Gould's wife.  She was away on business. If this means she saw anything, I don't know what.  We've questioned her at least five times.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: And, if it's a threat.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: We put her in a safe house.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: He's preaching.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Punishing.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: The sins were used in medieval sermons. There were seven cardinal virtues, and then seven deadly sins, created as a learning tool, because they distract from true worship.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Like in the Parson's Tale, and Dante.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Did you read them?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Yeah.  Parts of them.  Anyway, in Purgatory, Dante and his buddy are climbing up that big mountain... seeing all these other guys who sinned...

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Seven Terraces of Purgation.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Right.  But there, pride comes first, not gluttony.  The sins are in a different order.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: For now, let's just consider the books as the murderer's inspiration. The books and sermons are about atonement for sin.  And, these murders have been like forced attrition.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Forced what?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Attrition.  When you regret your sins, but not because you love God.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Like, because someone's holding a gun on you.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: No fingerprints?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Totally unrelated victims.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: No witnesses of any kind?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: None.  Which I don't understand.  He had to get back out.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: This is the one thing.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: What if it's not that she's seen something?  What if she's supposed to see something, but she just hasn't been given a chance to see it yet?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Okay.  But, what?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: You're sure your men didn't move this?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Even if they did, those photos were taken before forensics.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: It's got to be.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: What the fuck is that?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: A switchblade.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: There must be something.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: We're screwed.  He's fucking with us.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Bear with me.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Oh, yeah, sure.  You got to be kidding?!

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Just wait!

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Just, honestly... have you ever seen anything like this... been involved in anything like this?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: He just may be nuts enough.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: It doesn't fit.  He doesn't want us to help him stop.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Who the hell knows?  There's plenty of freaks out there doing dirty deeds they don't want to do.  You know... little voices tell them bad things.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: You meant what you said to Mrs. Gould, didn't you?  About catching this guy.  You really want to believe that, don't you?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: And you don't?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I wish I still thought like you.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Then, you tell me what you think we're doing.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: All we do is pick up the pieces.  We take all the evidence, and all the pictures and samples.  We write everything down and note what time things happened...

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Oh, that's all.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: We put it in a nice neat pile and file it away, on the slim chance it's ever needed in a courtroom.  It's like collecting diamonds on a desert island.  You keep them just in case you ever get rescued, but it's a pretty big ocean out there.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Bullshit.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I'm, sorry, but even the most promising clues usually lead only to other clues. I've seen so many corpses rolled away... unrevenged.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I've seen the same.  I'm not the country hick you seem to think I am.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: In this city, if all the skeletons came out of all the closets... if ever hidden body were to suddenly rise again, there'd be no more room for the living.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Does this make it with you?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Doesn't seem like our man, does it?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: You tell me.  I'm new in town.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: He doesn't have the desire somehow.  Our killer seems to have more purpose.  More purpose than Victor could ever conceive of.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: The fingerprints.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Yes.  They were there... so, it must be.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: We'll tag along.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Why would we?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Satisfy our curiosity?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Never in my twenty-four years, knock on wood.  I've only ever taken my gun out five times with the actual intention of using it.  Never fired it though.  Not once.  You?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Never took a bullet.  I pulled my gun once. fired it once.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: And?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: It was my first one of these.  We were a secondary unit, and I was pretty shaky going in.  I was still considered a rookie.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: How did the fire fight end?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I got him.  I got the son-of-a-bitch. See, I was doing really good up till then. Lots of street busts.  I've always had this weird luck... everything always went my way, but this was wild.  I got him with one shot... right between the eyes.  Next thing I know, the mayor's pinning a medal on me.  Picture in the paper, whole nine yards.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: How was it?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I expected it to be bad, you know.  I took a human life... but I slept like a baby that night.  I never gave it a second thought.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I think Hemingway wrote somewhere... I can't remember where, but he wrote that in order to live in a place like this, you have to have the ability to kill.  I think he meant you truly must be able to do it, not just faking it, too survive.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Sounds like he knew what he was talking about.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: It is Victor.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Call an ambulance.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: The way this has gone till now, I wouldn't have thought it was possible, but we may have underestimated this guy.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I want him bad.  I don't just want to catch him anymore.  I want to hurt him.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Listen to me.  He's all about playing games.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: No kidding!  No fucking kidding!

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: We have to divorce ourselves from emotions here.  No matter how hard it is, we have to stay focused on the details.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I don't know about you, but I feed off my emotions.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: He'll string us along all the way if we're not careful.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: How do those cockroaches get here so quick?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: They pay cops for the inside scoop, and they pay well.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Sorry about that... I just...

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Oh, it's alright.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Victor's landlord says an envelope of cash was in the office mailbox each month.  He says, quote, "I never heard a single complaint from the tenant in apartment three-o-one, and nobody ever complained about him.  He's the best tenant I've ever had.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: A landlord's dream tenant: a paralyzed man with no tongue.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Who pays the rent on time.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I'm sick of sitting around, waiting for him to kill again.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: This is the job.  It's not an Easter egg hunt.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: There must be something in this pile of garbage we can follow.  I mean, Christ... do we have to let this lunatic make all the moves.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: It's too dismissive to call him a lunatic. We can't make that mistake.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Oh, blah, blah, blah.  The guy's insane.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: It's a fine line between insane and inspired.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Hey, Freud, what brand of bullshit are you shoveling, huh?  Right now he's probably dancing around his room in a pair of his mommy's panties, singing show tunes and rubbing himself with peanut butter...

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Sooner or later his luck's goning to run out.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: No.  He's not depending on luck.  You've seen that.  We walked into that apartment exactly one year after he first tied Victor to the bed, to the day.  To the day! Because he wanted us to.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: We don't know for sure...

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Yes we do.  Here...

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: This quote... his first words to us.  I looked it up.  It's from Milton's Paradise Lost.  "Long is the way, and hard, that out of hell leads up to light... "

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: And so what?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Well, he's been right so far, hasn't he?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Just because the bastard has a library card, it doesn't make him Einstein.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Just, realize... this is not some common lunatic.  The type of intestinal fortitude it must take... to keep a man bound for a full year.  To connect tubes to his genitals.  To sever his hand and use it to plant fingerprints.  He's methodical and exacting, and worst of all, he's patient.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: What does all that matter anyway?  It's not our job to figure him out, is it?  All we have to do is catching him.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: How much money do you have?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I don't know... like fifty.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Well, that was money well spent.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Let's go.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: By telling you this, I'm trusting you more than I trust most people.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: It's be best if you got to the point, cause I'm about ready to punch you in the face.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: It's probably nothing, but even if it is, it's no skin off our teeth.  The man at Hot Dog World is a friend, in the Bureau.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Him?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: For a long time, the F.B.I.'s been hooked into the library system, keeping accurate records.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: What?  Assessing fines?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: They monitor reading habits.  Not every book, but certain ones are flagged.  Books about... let's say, how to build a nuclear bomb, or maybe Mein Kampf.  Whoever takes out a flagged book has their library records fed to the F.B.I. from then on.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: You got to be kidding.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Flagged books cover every topic the Bureau deems questionable... communism to violent crime.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: How is this legal?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Legal... illegal.  These terms don't apply. I don't applaud it.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: So they ran our list.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: If you want to know who's been reading Paradise Lost, Purgatory, and say... The Life and Time of Charlie Manson, the Bureau's computer will tell you.  It might give us a name.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Yeah.  Some college student who's taking English 101 and just happens to be writing a paper on Twentieth Century Crime.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Yeah, well... at least we're out of the office.  We've got pizza.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: How do you know all about this?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: I don't.  Neither do you.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: This is a waste of time.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: We're focusing.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I know, I know... focusing on one little thing.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: The Divine Comedy.  A History of Catholicism.  A book called Murderers and Madmen.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Modern Homicide Investigation.  In Cold Blood.  Of Human Bondage.  Human Bondage?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: It's not what you think it is.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: The Marquis de Sade and Origins of Sadism.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: That is.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: The Writings of Saint Thomas Aqu... Aquin...

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Saint Thomas Aquinas.  He wrote about the seven deadly sins.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: You're sure you're reading that right? John Doe?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: That's what it says.  Jonathan Doe.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: This is stupid.  It'd be just too easy.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: We'll take a look at him.  Talk to him.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Sure.  Uh, excuse me... are you by any chance a serial killer?  Oh, you are? Well, come with us then, if it's okay.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: What are you going to say?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: You do the talking.  Put that old silver tongue of yours to work.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Who told you about my silver tongue?  You been talking to my wife?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Are you alright?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I'm fine.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Wait... just wait.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: It was him.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: You can't go in there.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: The hell I can't!  We get in there and we can stop him.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: We need a warrant.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: We have probable cause now.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Think about it...

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: What the fuck is wrong with you?

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Think about how we got here!

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: By the time we clear a warrant someone else is going to be dead.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Think it through.  If we leave a hole like this, we'll never prosecute.  He'll walk.  We have to come up with some excuse for knocking on this door.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Okay... okay... get off.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: You stupid son of a...

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: No point in arguing anymore...

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: We had him.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: We could use about fifty more men here.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: I'm trying, alright?  Just tell me what we've got.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: Well, there are at least five thousand notebooks in this room, and near as I can tell, each notebook contains two hundred and fifty pages.

turns.speaker: MILLS
turns.text: Then, he must write about these murders.

turns.speaker: SOMERSET
turns.text: "What sick, ridiculous, puppets we are, and what a gross, little stage we dance on. What fun we have, dancing and fucking, not a care in the world.  Not knowing that we are nothing.  We are not what was intended."
